title: Rudeness or Aggression
description: Signs that a conversation participant is being rude, hostile, or aggressive

situations.strategy: Set clear boundaries, disengage if needed

conversation.speaker: User A
conversation.message: I think the solution to this problem is X because of these reasons...

conversation.speaker: User B
conversation.message: That's the stupidest thing I've ever heard. Only an idiot would think X works.

conversation.speaker: User A
conversation.message: I understand you disagree, but I'd appreciate if we could discuss this respectfully without personal attacks. If you have specific critiques of the approach, I'm open to hearing them.
conversation.note: Setting clear boundary while leaving door open for constructive dialogue

examples.explanation: User B uses direct insults rather than addressing the content of the argument. User A responds by clearly establishing a boundary around acceptable communication while still showing openness to meaningful discussion.

situations.strategy: Name the behavior directly, ask for clarification

conversation.speaker: Team Member A
conversation.message: Just finished the presentation for tomorrow!

conversation.speaker: Team Member B
conversation.message: Wow, finally done? I guess that's impressive for someone with your experience level.

conversation.speaker: Team Member A
conversation.message: That comment feels a bit dismissive. Is there something specific about the timing or my work that's concerning you?
conversation.note: Naming the behavior and asking for clarification

examples.explanation: Team Member B uses a passive-aggressive comment that appears to be a compliment but actually contains a dig. Team Member A directly addresses the tone without escalating and invites clarification.

situations.signals: Quick jump to hostility, out-of-proportion anger

conversation.speaker: Customer Service
conversation.message: I'm sorry, but that item is currently out of stock. We expect to have it available again next week.

conversation.speaker: Customer
conversation.message: Are you kidding me?! This is COMPLETELY UNACCEPTABLE! You people are absolutely incompetent! I need to speak to your manager RIGHT NOW!

conversation.speaker: Customer Service
conversation.message: I understand this is frustrating and disappointing. I'd be happy to connect you with a manager, or if you prefer, I can look into alternative options or a special arrangement. What would work best for you at this point?
conversation.note: De-escalation by acknowledging emotion and offering options

examples.explanation: Customer escalates rapidly with anger disproportionate to the situation. The service representative acknowledges the emotion without mirroring the hostility and offers constructive options to move forward.

situations.strategy: Assert value calmly, redirect to substance

conversation.speaker: Participant A
conversation.message: What if we tried approaching this from a different angle, like focusing on the community aspect first?

conversation.speaker: Participant B
conversation.message: Ugh, we've been over this already. That's not even worth discussing since it obviously wouldn't work in the real world.

conversation.speaker: Facilitator
conversation.message: Actually, I think there's value in exploring different perspectives. Participant A, could you elaborate on how you see that community-first approach working? What specific aspects would it address?
conversation.note: Asserting value of the contribution and redirecting to substance

examples.explanation: Participant B dismisses an idea without substantive critique. The facilitator calmly asserts the value of exploring different perspectives and redirects the conversation to the substance of the idea.
